title: Jack O'Garra
text:
John O'Garra (22 February 1891 – 15 January 1960) was an English <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> footballer who played as a <a href="halfback%20%28rugby%20league%29">halfback</a>. He played at club level for <a href="Widnes%20Vikings">Widnes</a> between 1908 and 1922, and at representative level for <a href="Lancashire%20rugby%20league%20team">Lancashire</a>. After retiring from rugby, he was elected onto the town council and became mayor of Widnes in 1945.
Playing career.
Club career.
O'Garra made his debut for Widnes in 1908. In March 1921, O'Garra and teammate <a href="Arthur%20Johnson%20%28rugby%20league%29">Arthur Johnson</a> were granted a <a href="Benefit%20%28sports%29">benefit</a> match in recognition of their service at Widnes.
Representative career.
O'Garra made two appearances for <a href="Lancashire%20rugby%20league%20team">Lancashire</a> in the 1913–14 <a href="County%20Championship%20%28rugby%20league%29">County Championship</a>, scoring one try in a 24–3 win against <a href="Cumberland%20rugby%20league%20team">Cumberland</a>.
O'Garra was also selected for the <a href="1914%20Great%20Britain%20Lions%20tour%20of%20Australia%20and%20New%20Zealand">1914 Great Britain Lions tour of Australia and New Zealand</a>. He scored five tries in eight appearances, but did not appear in any <a href="Test%20%28rugby%20league%29">Test</a> matches.
Outside of rugby league.
In July 1922, O'Garra married Janet Barker at <a href="St%20Marie%27s%20Church%2C%20Widnes">St Marie's Church, Widnes</a>. 
After ending his rugby career, O'Garra became the licensee of the Grosvenor Hotel in Widnes. He was elected onto the Widnes town council in 1931, and became mayor of the town in 1945.
